block.p: U.S. Believes Submarine Was Sunk by Bad Torpdeo Acoustical tapes made by the American submarine Memphis in the Barents Sea and by other vessels are the source of the American theory that a faulty torpedo caused the explosion that sank the Russian submarine Kursk, American officials said. They said the evidence did not support Russian suggestions that a collision with another sub, a ship or some other object had occurred.

High-Altitude Moscow Fire Firefighters worked for nearly 26 hours to put out a blaze that engulfed the 1,772-foot Ostankino television tower, Europe's tallest structure and Moscow's communications hub. Two people were known to have died and a third was missing.

Retrial for New Yorker in Peru A military tribunal has rescinded the life sentence of Lori Berenson, 30, a New York woman accused of terrorism and treason, and granted her a new trial in civilian courts. But human rights organizations cautioned that the decision did not mean she would get a fair trial. In 1996, Ms. Berenson was tried in secret before a tribunal of military judges wearing ski masks to conceal their identities. Her lawyers were not permitted to cross-examine witnesses.

U.S. Chides Cuba Over Visas The State Department accused Cuba of causing widespread suffering by refusing to let Cubans leave the island even if they held United States visas. Separately, officials said, the United States has told Ricardo Alarcon, the president of the Cuban National Assembly, that he cannot attend a meeting of international lawmakers at the United Nations.

Mexico Anti-Abortion Bill The governor of Guanajuato has sent back to the state congress for further study a bill that would have made the state the only one to extend the ban on abortions to cases of rape. The governor's aides said the action amounted to a veto. Abortion rights groups hailed the move as a rebuff to conservative politicians and church leaders seeking to chip away at already limited rights to abortion.

Burundi Negotiations Snagged Negotiations to end a seven-year civil war became bogged down when some Tutsi minority parties refused to sign a deal with the Hutu majority, dashing President Clinton's hopes of witnessing the signing of a major peace deal and cease-fire.
Warrant Dismissed in Turkey A state security court in Istanbul dismissed an arrest warrant for Fetullah Gulen, an Islamic leader accused by prosecutors of trying to overthrow the secular government.

New Effort on Kosovo Violence Britain's Royal Marines spearheaded a campaign against ethnic violence in Kosovo after a series of killings of Serbs underlined the failure of NATO-led forces to stem ethnic violence in the province. The new commander of peacekeeping troops in the central region of Kosovo announced that fixed checkpoints would be replaced by patrols to seek out troublemakers.

House Speaker Yields On Raising Minimum Wage Speaker J. Dennis Hastert offered key concessions to Democrats on raising the federal minimum wage to $6.15 an hour, moving to end a stalemate on an issue that Republicans feared could hurt them at the polls.

Support for Scouts Cools Corporate and governmental support for the Boy Scouts has slipped in the two months since the Supreme Court ruled that the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to exclude gays. A common concern is that by contributing to or allowing a group that bans gays to use facilities, a government or business may be violating local antidiscrimination statutes or corporate rules.

Whitewater Inquiry Timetable Robert W. Ray, the independent counsel, said he expected to issue a statement of his findings and conclusions about the Whitewater investigation a few weeks before New York voters go to the polls to choose between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio, her Republican opponent for the United States Senate. He also said he would wait until shortly after President Clinton left office to announce whether he would seek an indictment of Mr. Clinton in connection with his affair with a White House intern.

Gore Names Drug Companies Vice President Al Gore escalated his attacks on the pharmaceutical industry, calling for greater competition and singling out Schering-Plough, which makes the allergy medication Claritin, and American Home Products, the parent of Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, which makes Lodine, an arthritis medicine.

Religion and Politics The Anti-Defamation League asked Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman to avoid ''overt expressions'' of religious belief on the campaign trail because, in a political context, they are ''contrary to the American ideal.''

Bush Assails Gore on Schools Gov. George W. Bush said the Clinton administration had complacently presided over ''a national tragedy'' of public school decline. He also said would unveil a proposal next week to have the government subsidize prescription drug purchases by the low-income elderly.

Bush Balks on Debate Plans The Bush campaign has raised objections over format, one site and network coverage of three presidential debates proposed by an independent commission that has set up such debates since 1988.

Higher Test Scores for Blacks Black public school students who switched to private schools on scholarships similar to vouchers performed significantly higher on standardized math and reading tests than similar students who remained in public schools, a study found.

Judge Allots $8 Million In Settlement of Attica Suit A federal judge divided up an $8 million settlement to compensate more than 500 families for abuse inflicted on inmates by the state police during the 1971 Attica prison uprising that left 43 people dead.

Lazio Makes Tax Returns Public Aides to Representative Rick A. Lazio provided limited access to 10 years of the congressman's federal and state returns, in an effort to end speculation about his finances and pressure from the Democrats.

Man Stole Houses, Officials Say Brooklyn prosecutors said a Long Island man, Kevin Walker, 35, forged deeds that he used to get $900,000 in mortgage loans and to sell some of the properties to unwitting buyers for a total of more than $700,000.

School for Sale The Lycee Francais de New York, the prestigious school that attracts Europeans and American Francophiles, is selling its six buildings on the Upper East Side to create an endowment and build a new school.
Arts Center for Woodstock Governor Pataki said the state would contribute $15 million toward a $40 million performing arts and music center on the site of the first Woodstock festival in Bethel, N.Y.

Board Scolds Safir for Trip The city's Conflict of Interest Board publicly rebuked former Police Commissioner Howard Safir for accepting a free trip to the Academy Awards last year from the chief executive of Revlon.

Study Questions Heart Drug The second-most popular kind of drug used to lower high blood pressure, calcium channel blockers, has been shown to be less effective than other drugs in preventing heart attacks and heart failure.

Concern for Venezuela Tires Bridgestone/Firestone asked its dealers in Venezuela to return to the factory any unsold 15- and 16-inch light truck tires made there. But the tiremaker rebuffed Ford's request for a recall of identical tires already in use on vehicles in Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador.

New Bailout Deal Sought Rizal Ramli, Indonesia's new economic czar, said the I.M.F. had become overly involved in the nuts and bolts of the country's economy in the course of its $43 billion bailout. He said the agreement with the I.M.F. should be renegotiated.
Doping Tests for Olympics The International Olympic Committee's executive board approved plans for testing for the banned synthetic hormone EPO at the Summer Games in Sydney, Australia.
U.S. Open Tennis Martina Hingis, Venus Williams, Monica Seles, Jennifer Capriati and Pete Sampras all won their matches on a soggy opening day.
Editorials: Prayers at football games; endorsements for the Bronx; a C.I.A. cover-up on Chile; transgender rights.
